items.text: I love being the center of attention at parties and social gatherings.
items.rationale: Seeking social attention and enjoying large gatherings is a core marker of Eysenckian Extraversion.

items.text: I find it easy to strike up conversations with complete strangers.
items.rationale: Sociability and ease of social initiation are central to Extraversion in the PEN model.

items.text: I get bored quickly if I'm not doing something exciting or stimulating.
items.rationale: Sensation-seeking and need for external stimulation reflect the cortical arousal theory underlying Eysenck's Extraversion.

items.text: People describe me as the life of the party.
items.rationale: Third-person observation of social dominance and liveliness is a prototypical Extraversion descriptor.

items.text: I tend to act on impulse rather than thinking things through carefully.
items.rationale: Impulsivity is a key component of Eysenck's Extraversion dimension, distinct from Big Five models.

items.text: I would much rather spend my weekend at a lively event than staying home alone.
items.rationale: Preference for social stimulation over solitude directly taps the Extraversion-Introversion continuum.

items.text: I have a wide circle of friends and acquaintances.
items.rationale: Breadth of social network is a behavioral indicator of high sociability, a core Extraversion facet.

items.text: I often crave new experiences and thrills.
items.rationale: Sensation-seeking and novelty-craving reflect the low baseline arousal characteristic of Eysenckian extraverts.

items.text: I feel energized after spending time with a large group of people.
items.rationale: Gaining energy from social interaction is a hallmark subjective experience of Extraversion.

items.text: I usually speak before I think, and it sometimes gets me into trouble.
items.rationale: Verbal impulsivity is a well-established behavioral marker of Extraversion in Eysenck's framework.

items.text: I enjoy taking risks just for the fun of it.
items.rationale: Risk-taking for excitement maps onto the sensation-seeking and impulsivity facets of Extraversion.

items.text: I can easily liven up a dull social situation.
items.rationale: Social assertiveness and the ability to energize groups are prototypical extravert behaviors.

items.text: I sometimes do things on the spur of the moment that I later regret.
items.rationale: Impulsive action with regret taps Extraversion's impulsivity facet but the regret component could suggest Neuroticism.

items.text: I like to keep busy and always have something going on.
items.rationale: Activity level is associated with Extraversion but could also reflect low Neuroticism or general temperament.

items.text: I sometimes take risks without fully considering the consequences, and I feel guilty about it afterward.
items.rationale: The risk-taking maps to Extraversion's impulsivity, but the guilt and rumination could indicate Neuroticism.

items.text: I prefer spending my evenings reading a book rather than going out to socialize.
items.rationale: Preference for solitary intellectual activity over social engagement is a core Introversion marker.

items.text: Large social gatherings leave me feeling drained and exhausted.
items.rationale: Energy depletion from social stimulation reflects the high baseline cortical arousal theorized for introverts.

items.text: I tend to think carefully before I speak or act.
items.rationale: Deliberation and low impulsivity are characteristic of the introverted pole in Eysenck's model.

items.text: I have a small number of close friends rather than a large social circle.
items.rationale: Preference for depth over breadth in relationships is a well-established Introversion indicator.

items.text: I find small talk tedious and would rather have a deep, meaningful conversation.
items.rationale: Discomfort with superficial social exchange and preference for depth reflects introverted social style.

items.text: I need a lot of quiet time to recharge after a busy day.
items.rationale: Need for solitary recovery from stimulation is consistent with Eysenck's arousal theory of Introversion.

items.text: People sometimes mistake my quietness for unfriendliness, but I'm just reserved.
items.rationale: Social reserve being misinterpreted is a common lived experience of introverts, distinct from social anxiety.

items.text: I rarely seek out excitement or thrilling experiences.
items.rationale: Low sensation-seeking directly reflects the introverted end of Eysenck's Extraversion dimension.

items.text: I prefer working alone rather than in a team.
items.rationale: Preference for solitary work environments is a behavioral manifestation of Introversion.

items.text: I enjoy routines and predictable schedules more than spontaneous plans.
items.rationale: Preference for predictability over novelty reflects low sensation-seeking characteristic of introverts.

items.text: I often observe social situations from the sidelines rather than jumping in.
items.rationale: Social observation rather than participation is a prototypical introverted behavioral pattern.

items.text: I feel most like myself when I am alone with my own thoughts.
items.rationale: Subjective authenticity in solitude is a core experiential marker of Introversion.

items.text: I sometimes avoid social events because I find them overwhelming.
items.rationale: Social avoidance due to overstimulation maps to Introversion, but 'overwhelming' could suggest Neuroticism-related anxiety.

items.text: I don't like drawing attention to myself in group settings.
items.rationale: Avoiding social attention is introverted, but could also reflect social anxiety associated with Neuroticism.

items.text: I feel anxious and uncomfortable when I have to make conversation at a party.
items.rationale: Social discomfort at parties could reflect Introversion (low sociability) or Neuroticism (social anxiety).

items.text: I worry about things much more than most people do.
items.rationale: Excessive worry is a hallmark of high Neuroticism reflecting autonomic nervous system lability.

items.text: My mood can shift dramatically from one moment to the next.
items.rationale: Emotional lability and mood instability are core features of Eysenckian Neuroticism.

items.text: I often feel tense and on edge for no apparent reason.
items.rationale: Free-floating anxiety and tension directly reflect the high autonomic arousal in Neuroticism.

items.text: I frequently lose sleep because something is bothering me.
items.rationale: Sleep disruption due to rumination is a well-established behavioral consequence of high Neuroticism.

items.text: I tend to dwell on things that have gone wrong in my life.
items.rationale: Rumination about negative events is a cognitive hallmark of Neuroticism.

items.text: I often feel inadequate compared to other people.
items.rationale: Chronic feelings of inadequacy and low self-esteem are central to the Neuroticism construct.

items.text: Even minor setbacks can leave me feeling upset for a long time.
items.rationale: Disproportionate emotional reactivity to minor stressors reflects the emotional instability of Neuroticism.

items.text: I am easily hurt by criticism, even when it is constructive.
items.rationale: Hypersensitivity to criticism reflects the emotional vulnerability characteristic of high Neuroticism.

items.text: I sometimes feel a sense of dread or panic without any clear cause.
items.rationale: Spontaneous panic and dread reflect the autonomic lability central to Eysenck's Neuroticism dimension.

items.text: I find it very difficult to relax, even when I have nothing to worry about.
items.rationale: Chronic inability to relax reflects persistent autonomic arousal associated with Neuroticism.

items.text: I often feel guilty about things I have said or done.
items.rationale: Excessive guilt and self-blame are affective markers of high Neuroticism.

items.text: I consider myself a nervous person who gets stressed easily.
items.rationale: Self-identified nervousness and stress reactivity are direct self-report indicators of Neuroticism.

items.text: I sometimes feel lonely even when I am surrounded by people.
items.rationale: Subjective loneliness despite social presence suggests emotional distress, but could also reflect Introversion.

items.text: I get irritable and snappy when things don't go my way.
items.rationale: Irritability under frustration maps to Neuroticism's emotional reactivity, but hostility could suggest Psychoticism.

items.text: When I'm angry, I sometimes say cruel things that I don't really mean.
items.rationale: Emotional outbursts map to Neuroticism, but cruelty and lack of empathy in the moment could indicate Psychoticism.

items.text: I don't really care what other people think of me.
items.rationale: Indifference to social evaluation reflects the tough-mindedness and low conformity central to Psychoticism.

items.text: I find it difficult to feel empathy for people who are suffering.
items.rationale: Low empathy is one of the most robust markers of Eysenck's Psychoticism dimension.

items.text: Rules and social conventions seem pointless to me most of the time.
items.rationale: Disregard for social norms and conventions is a core feature of Psychoticism.

items.text: I enjoy making people uncomfortable just to see how they react.
items.rationale: Deliberate provocation and enjoyment of others' discomfort reflects the callousness of high Psychoticism.

items.text: I would have no problem stepping on others to get what I want.
items.rationale: Willingness to exploit others for personal gain reflects the egocentric and antisocial nature of Psychoticism.

items.text: People have told me that I can be cold and unfeeling.
items.rationale: Third-person feedback about emotional coldness is a prototypical behavioral indicator of Psychoticism.

items.text: I sometimes enjoy the idea of causing chaos or disruption.
items.rationale: Attraction to disorder and antisocial disruption is characteristic of high Psychoticism.

items.text: I find it hard to understand why people get so emotional about things.
items.rationale: Inability to comprehend others' emotional reactions reflects the empathy deficit in Psychoticism.

items.text: I believe that loyalty and trust are overrated concepts.
items.rationale: Devaluing interpersonal bonds reflects the detachment and tough-mindedness of Psychoticism.

items.text: I have been in trouble with authority figures more than most people.
items.rationale: Conflict with authority reflects the antisocial and nonconforming behavioral pattern of Psychoticism.

items.text: I can be quite manipulative when I need to get my way.
items.rationale: Interpersonal manipulation is a behavioral expression of the callous, egocentric aspect of Psychoticism.

items.text: I don't feel much remorse when I've hurt someone's feelings.
items.rationale: Lack of remorse after causing harm is a defining characteristic of high Psychoticism.

items.text: I prefer to make decisions based on logic alone, without letting emotions get in the way.
items.rationale: Purely logical decision-making reflects tough-mindedness but could also be a rational coping style unrelated to Psychoticism.

items.text: I get bored with people very quickly and move on.
items.rationale: Shallow interpersonal engagement maps to Psychoticism's detachment, but could also reflect Extraversion's novelty-seeking.

items.text: I love the thrill of doing something dangerous, even if it could hurt someone.
items.rationale: Thrill-seeking maps to Extraversion's sensation-seeking, but disregard for harm to others pushes toward Psychoticism.

items.text: I generally feel calm and composed, even in stressful situations.
items.rationale: Emotional composure under stress is the defining feature of the stable pole of Eysenck's Neuroticism dimension.

items.text: I rarely feel anxious or worried about the future.
items.rationale: Low anxiety and minimal worry directly reflect emotional stability in the PEN model.

items.text: I bounce back quickly from disappointments and setbacks.
items.rationale: Emotional resilience and rapid recovery from negative events are hallmarks of Stability.

items.text: My mood is generally steady and predictable throughout the day.
items.rationale: Mood consistency and low emotional variability are core indicators of emotional Stability.

items.text: I don't take criticism personally; I see it as an opportunity to improve.
items.rationale: Constructive response to criticism without emotional distress reflects low Neuroticism and high Stability.

items.text: I feel confident in my ability to handle whatever life throws at me.
items.rationale: Self-efficacy and confidence in coping reflect the secure emotional foundation of Stability.

items.text: I sleep well at night and rarely lie awake worrying.
items.rationale: Good sleep quality without rumination is a behavioral marker of low autonomic arousal and Stability.

items.text: People often come to me for advice because I stay level-headed in a crisis.
items.rationale: Being sought out for emotional steadiness is a third-person validation of high Stability.

items.text: I can let go of mistakes and move on without dwelling on them.
items.rationale: Absence of rumination and ability to move past errors reflects emotional Stability.

items.text: I feel secure in who I am and don't need constant reassurance from others.
items.rationale: Emotional self-sufficiency and secure self-concept are characteristic of the stable personality.

items.text: I handle pressure well and perform effectively under tight deadlines.
items.rationale: Performance maintenance under pressure reflects low stress reactivity, a core Stability feature.

items.text: I rarely feel overwhelmed by my emotions.
items.rationale: Emotional regulation and not being overwhelmed by affect directly indicate Stability.

items.text: I tend to see the positive side of most situations.
items.rationale: Optimistic cognitive style is associated with Stability but could also reflect Extraversion's positive affect.

items.text: I find it easy to forgive people and don't hold grudges.
items.rationale: Forgiveness reflects low hostility and emotional equilibrium, but could also indicate low Psychoticism (agreeableness).

items.text: I feel happy and content most of the time, and I enjoy being around others.
items.rationale: General contentment maps to Stability, but enjoyment of social contact and positive affect could indicate Extraversion.
